summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary sworn interview conducted by the DOJ Office of the Inspector General (OIG) with a Federal Bureau of Prisons Lieutenant on March 16, 2022. The interview is part of an OIG investigation into the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein, focusing on camera system failures, phone call procedures, and emergency response protocols at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York in August 2019.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate whose death on August 9-10, 2019, is the subject of the OIG investigation. The interview discusses the circumstances around his death, including a phone call he was allegedly allowed to make.

persons.name: Lieutenant T. M.
persons.context: The witness being interviewed. He was the SIS Lieutenant at MCC New York in August 2019. He discusses discovering camera system failures, reporting them, and his knowledge of events surrounding Epstein's death.

persons.name: Special Agent
persons.context: The primary OIG agent conducting the interview. He asks detailed questions about camera systems, phone logs, and BOP procedures.

persons.name: Hughwon
persons.context: BOP communications technician responsible for fixing the camera system. The witness states he notified Hughwon of the camera failure on August 8, 2019, and discussed repairs on subsequent days.

persons.name: Captain
persons.context: The Captain at MCC New York whom the witness states he notified about the camera system failure on August 8, 2019. There is a discrepancy about when the Captain was informed.

persons.name: Tova Noel
persons.context: Correctional Officer who was on duty in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) when Epstein was discovered. The interview asks about procedures for hitting emergency body alarms.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: Correctional Officer on duty in the SHU with Tova Noel when Epstein was discovered.

persons.name: Unit Manager
persons.context: Unit manager who, according to hearsay relayed by the witness, allegedly allowed Jeffrey Epstein to make a phone call on August 9, 2019.

connections.description: Lieutenant T.M. reported the camera system failure to communications technician Hughwon and later discussed the repair status with him.
Lieutenant T.M. states he reported the camera system failure to his Captain, though there is a discrepancy about the timing of this report.
They were together reviewing cameras when the playback failure was first discovered on August 8, 2019.

events.title: Camera System Failure Discovered
events.description: Lieutenant T.M. discovers the NiceVision camera system at MCC New York is not recording and many camera feeds are completely blacked out. He reports it to technician Hughwon and Captain.

events.title: Epstein's Alleged Phone Call
events.description: According to hearsay relayed by the witness, Unit Manager allowed Jeffrey Epstein to make a phone call, allegedly to his deceased mother. A 21-minute call log from the SHU exists for that evening.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is found deceased in his cell in the Special Housing Unit at MCC New York. The interview examines procedures and failures surrounding the event.

events.title: Witness Writes Memo on Camera Failure
events.description: Lieutenant T.M. writes a memorandum documenting the camera system failure he discovered on August 8th, which is later provided to OIG.

events.title: OIG Sworn Interview
events.description: The DOJ OIG conducts a voluntary sworn interview with BOP Lieutenant T.M. as part of its investigation into the events surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death.

SIS office at MCC New York
keyFacts: The witness discovered a major failure of the MCC New York camera system on August 8, 2019, with many cameras blacked out and none recording, which was reported but not fully resolved before Epstein's death.

A 21-minute phone call was placed from the Special Housing Unit on August 9, 2019, at approximately 6:58 PM, which the witness believes through hearsay was Epstein being allowed a call by a Unit Manager.

The witness states that allowing an inmate to make an unmonitored personal call on a legal line was against BOP policy and a security risk, as it could not be reviewed for threats or witness intimidation.

There are discrepancies in the timeline: the witness is confident he reported the camera failure to the Captain on August 8th, but the Captain stated he wasn't told until August 10th, and the witness's own memo was dated August 10th.

The interview reveals standard BOP emergency procedures, including that hitting a 'body alarm' should trigger a response from all available staff within 2-3 minutes, and such events are logged in a control officer logbook.
